I’m Jeremy Begbie. I teach at the Divinity
School. My original professional training

9.text:
was in music, and I’m interested in the
intersections between music and faith and

13.text:
music and theology. Not so long ago, I was
asked to play some piano music before a wedding

18.text: service at a church near Duke. The idea was to create an atmosphere of quiet expectation

25.text: as the congregation gathered. But as the congregation grew, so did the noise level—exponentially.

32.text:
This lot just wouldn’t stop talking. The
louder I played, the louder they got. [LAUGHTER]

38.text:
I tried everything, from Bach to bebop, but
nothing would get this crowd of hypertalkative

45.text: American Presbyterians to shut up. [LAUGHTER] So I thought, “Hmm. Well, shall I risk it?”

54.text: [PLAYS DOWNTON ABBEY THEME ON PIANO] Total silence. [LAUGHTER]

68.text: I could only assume that I was tapping into something deep in their psyche, some primal memory of a home that

75.text: they’d long forgotten. Half-remembered British accents, green summers, country gardens, going

81.text: downstairs to tell the servants off—[LAUGHTER]—going upstairs to take your hat off. And the music

87.text:
was putting them in touch with their inner
colonial, their inner Englishness. What a

94.text: wonderful experience that was. Ray has been talking about stories. He’s been saying

98.text:
if you want to tap deep into the patient,
listen to the stories. Stories help us see,

105.text:
hear, express, and understand experience.
I want to give you a kind of musical take

109.text:
on that, and argue that music helps us see,
hear, express, and understand experience.

117.text: If you want to get at what makes someone tick, if you want to find out what’s going on,

122.text: if you want to understand a congregation before a wedding, if you want to get in touch with

127.text:
the inner Englishness of an American, try
playing music. Don’t ask them about biology.

134.text: Play some music. Music also works by telling stories, but not in words, rather in notes

141.text: or tones, in pitch sounds that dance and jostle with each other in songs and symphonies. Ray’s

149.text:
been saying there was a kind of basic story
behind all stories, or most stories, and the

154.text:
same goes for music—or at least the kind
of music we know best. The type of music we

159.text: know best flowered in the late—well, actually, early 17th century, and it’s usually called

163.text:
tonal music or Western tonal music, and it
surrounds us today in shopping malls, in restaurants,

170.text:
in radios, indeed, whether it’s Beethoven
or bebop or folk rock, R&B, hip-hop, or trip-hop—it’s

177.text:
Western tonal music. And there’s kind of
a basic story underlining this kind of music,

183.text:
and surprise, surprise—it’s shaped very
like the one Ray’s been telling. Let’s

188.text: try to hear it. How did you wake up this morning? Did you need an alarm to wake you up? How

193.text: many people woke up with an alarm? Some people did, but not everyone. Okay, well, you can

198.text: imagine yourself asleep, and suddenly—suddenly, very early in the morning, perhaps it goes

204.text: off, and you ram your hand down all over the bedside table to try to find the button, shoving

209.text:
off whatever you read and—like, um, the
collected works of Richard Brodhead or whatever

213.text: you had beside there [ph]—[LAUGHTER]—and eventually your sleepy hand finds the right

218.text: button. Tension, resolution—one of the most basic psychological patterns governing our

225.text:
lives, from traffic lights on red to traffic
lights on green, from nerves before the dentist

230.text:
to relief when it’s all over. From sounds
like this—[CHORD ON PIANO]—to sounds like

237.text: that—[CHORD RESOLVES]. You hear this in this culture—[FIRST CHORD]—you expect,

242.text: want, desire that—[RESOLVED CHORD]. It was said of Mozart if he heard this—[ASCENDING SCALE, INCOMPLETE]

247.text: —even if he was asleep and two stories up, he’d wake up, run all

252.text: the way downstairs—[RESOLVED CHORD TO COMPLETE SCALE]—just to play that—[LAUGHTER]—

255.text: because he couldn’t bear that—[UNRESOLVED CHORD]—unresolved. [RESOLVED CHORD] And writing Western music

260.text: is about handling the dynamic space between that——[UNRESOLVED CHORD]—or sounds like

265.text: it—and that [RESOLVED CHORD]. It all depends how you resolve your tensions. And as your

270.text:
therapist will tell you, there are many ways
of resolving your tension. One of the most

276.text:
interesting is this device, and it’s called
an appoggiatura. [PLAYS APPOGGIATURA EXAMPLES

283.text: THROUGHOUT] That first little note is dissonant with the chord underneath, and it’s quickly

291.text:
resolved. Here’s another one. Barber—do
you recognize that? [PLAYS “ADAGIO FOR STRINGS”]

302.text: Barber “Adagio for Strings.” Here it comes—[HUMS ALONG WITH THE APPOGGIATURA]

311.text: —that’s an appoggiatura. John Sloboda of Keele University, a very distinguished music psychologist, done

315.text: a lot of research on the appoggiatura, because he’s found that over and over again in music

320.text: that people say moves them very deeply, you will find a preponderance of appoggiaturas.

325.text: Take this one—[PLAYS “YESTERDAY” PAUSES]. [AUDIENCE HUMS MISSING APPOGGIATURA] Thank

337.text: you. [LAUGHTER] [RESUMES PLAYING] Boy, they take a bit of warming up, don’t they? [HUMS APPOGGIATURA]

343.text: There’s an appoggiatura. Here’s another. Now, I’m going to take out these

352.text:
appoggiaturas, I’m going to fill them out,
all right, so we’re just left with everything

356.text: but appoggiaturas. [PLAYS ADULTERATED VERSION OF “YESTERDAY”] Would you buy it? [LAUGHTER]

369.text: Would you know that in 40 years? I changed only two little notes. But that’s only one

376.text:
find of tension resolution. There are many
others, and the cumulative effect of all these

381.text:
is to pull you forward. You want or desire
the next sound, or any number of sounds, in

386.text:
the future. What could be more appropriate
than for this event?
